Chapter 10: Eliminating Karmic Hindrances Question:
Is it only by remembering Buddhas such as AmitÃ¢bha and other bodhisattvas who have attained the stage of nonretrogression that there are other skillful means?
Answer:

Those who seek the stage of nonretrogression should not only recollect, chant the name, and pay homage, but should also repent, make offerings, rejoice, and dedicate their merits in the presence of the Buddhas.
Question:
What does this refer to?
Answer:
The Buddhas in the ten directions know everything without exception,
I now confess all my dark evil deeds before them.
There are nine kinds of evil deeds, combined in groups of three, arising from the three kinds of afflictions,
I repent of all these evil deeds committed in this life or in previous lives.
If I am to receive the retribution for evil deeds in the three evil paths,
I wish to repay them in this very life, and not enter the evil paths to receive them.
The Buddhas in the ten directions refers to all the Buddhas in the present who have attained longevity and have not yet entered nirvana.
The ten directions are the four cardinal directions, the four intermediate directions, and the zenith and nadir.
Buddha refers to one who knows all knowable things without exception.
Confession means confessing all one's faults before the Buddhas without concealing anything, and not committing them again in the future, like building a dike to hold back water.
Black evil means lacking wisdom, understanding, and illumination, thus often committing many evil deeds, whether unwholesome or obscured indeterminate.
Three kinds means evil arising from body, speech, and mind;
retribution in the present life, retribution in the next life, and retribution in future lives;
committing oneself, causing others to commit, and rejoicing in the commission.
Arising from three kinds of afflictions, the three kinds of afflictions are those bound to the desire realm, those bound to the form realm, and those bound to the formless realm;
aiding the affliction of craving, aiding the affliction of anger, and aiding the affliction of delusion;
upper afflictions, middle afflictions, and lower afflictions.
Repenting of all evil done in this life and past lives means repenting without remainder of the many evils committed in this world and past lives.
The hells are the eight hot hells and the ten cold ice hells.
The animal realm refers to those born on land, in water, those without feet, those with two feet, and those with many feet.
The hungry ghost realm refers to those who eat saliva, vomit, wash water, pus, blood, feces, urine, and so forth.
If I should experience these three evil destinies due to my past actions, may I experience the consequences of those offenses in this very body.
If I am to experience them in my next life, may I not experience them in the hells, hungry ghost realm, or animal realm.
Furthermore, the Buddha himself taught the method of repentance.
If a bodhisattva wishes to repent of offenses, they should say:

In the present ten directions of the world, all Buddhas have attained supreme perfect enlightenment, turned the Dharma wheel, rained down the Dharma, beaten the Dharma drum, blown the Dharma conch, and erected the Dharma banner.
Satisfying sentient beings with the gift of Dharma, benefiting and comforting them, and having compassion for the world, benefiting gods and humans.
I now with my body, speech, and mind, bow my head to the feet of the Buddhas of the present, the Buddhas who know, see, are the eyes of the world, and are the lamps of the world.
From beginningless cyclic existence up to now, I have committed offenses due to being oppressed by greed, anger, and delusion. I may not have recognized the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha;
or may not have recognized what is sinful or meritorious;
or may have committed many offenses with my body, speech, and mind;
or may have maliciously drawn blood from the Buddha's body;
or may have destroyed the true Dharma, broken up the Sangha, or killed an arhat;
or may myself have engaged in the ten unwholesome courses of action, or have taught others to do so, or have rejoiced in them;
or may have spoken unloving words to sentient beings;
If one deceives others with false weights and measures, or troubles sentient beings with various wrongdoings;
Or if one is unfilial to one's parents;
Or if one steals from stupas or the fourfold assembly;
If one violates the sutras and precepts taught by the Buddha, or goes against one's preceptor or teacher;
If one speaks ill of and despises those who have given rise to the vehicle of the hearers, the vehicle of the solitary realizers, or the Great Vehicle, out of resentment;
Because of the mind covered by stinginess and jealousy, one may speak harshly to the buddhas;
Or one may say that what is the Dharma is not the Dharma, and say that what is not the Dharma is the Dharma.
Now, in the presence of the buddhas who know, see, and realize, I fully reveal all these offenses without concealing anything, and from now on I dare not commit them again.

If I have committed offenses that should cause me to fall into the hells, animal realms, hungry ghost realms, or asuras, not encountering the Three Jewels, and to be born in various difficulties, I wish to experience the consequences of these offenses in this very life.

Just as the past bodhisattvas who sought the Buddha Way repented their evil karmic offenses, I also in the same way confess and repent, not daring to conceal them, and will not commit them again in the future.

If the present bodhisattvas who seek the Buddha Way repent their evil karmic offenses, I also in the same way confess and repent, not daring to conceal them, and will not commit them again in the future.

Just as the future bodhisattvas who seek the Buddha Way will repent their evil karmic offenses, I also in the same way confess and repent, not daring to conceal them, and will not commit them again in the future.

Just as the past, future, and present bodhisattvas who seek the Buddha Way have repented, are repenting, and will repent their evil karmic offenses, I also in the same way repent my evil karmic offenses, not daring to conceal them, and will not commit them again in the future.
Question:
You have already explained the method of repentance, how does one make requests?
Answer:
All the Buddhas in the ten directions, who are presently attaining enlightenment,
I request them to turn the Dharma wheel, to bring peace and joy to all beings;
All the Buddhas in the ten directions, if they wish to give up their lives,
I now bow my head to them, requesting them to remain for a long time.
Turning the Dharma wheel refers to expounding the meaning of the Four Noble Truths in three turns and twelve aspects:

This is the truth of suffering, this is the origin of suffering, this is the cessation of suffering, this is the path leading to the cessation of suffering. This is called the first turn with four aspects.

This truth of suffering should be known, this origin of suffering should be eliminated, this cessation of suffering should be realized, this path leading to the cessation of suffering should be cultivated. This is called the second turn with four aspects.

This truth of suffering has been known, this origin of suffering has been eliminated, this cessation of suffering has been realized, this path leading to the cessation of suffering has been cultivated. This is called the third turn with four aspects.
The four aspects refer to the arising of the eye, knowledge, wisdom, and enlightenment within the Four Noble Truths.
Some say:
The vehicles of the hearers, solitary realizers, and the Great Vehicle, these are called the Dharma wheel.
Explaining the meaning of these three vehicles is called turning the Dharma wheel.

As for bringing peace and happiness to all beings, the pleasures of the five desires are not called peace and happiness. It is bringing peace and happiness to the present world and future lives, and entering the three vehicles, that is called peace and happiness.

This person encourages and requests the Buddhas to turn the Dharma wheel, enabling all beings to experience the bliss of nirvana. If they have not yet attained nirvana, they are made to experience worldly bliss. For this reason, it is said to bring peace and happiness.

As for lifespan, due to the causes and conditions of receiving karmic retribution, the life faculty continues and is able to abide, like a transformation created by the mind, abiding according to karmic actions. When the karmic actions of the mind cease, it is extinguished.
Encouraging and requesting is called sincerely seeking and vowing.
The Buddhas regard all beings, great and small, as no different. For this reason, seeking and requesting with the hope of fulfilling one's wishes:
Do not abandon your lifespan, but abide for immeasurable asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas to liberate beings.
Furthermore, the Buddha himself explained the method of requesting, and bodhisattvas should say:

I pay homage to the buddhas of the present ten directions who have just attained supreme perfect enlightenment and have not yet turned the wheel of Dharma. I now request them to turn the wheel of Dharma, beat the Dharma drum, blow the Dharma conch, erect the Dharma banner, perform great Dharma sacrifices, and light the great Dharma torch. With this Dharma offering, may they satisfy sentient beings, bring them much benefit and peace, have compassion for the world, and benefit gods and humans. For this reason, I now request.
This is called requesting the buddhas to turn the wheel of Dharma.
As for abiding for a long time, one should also say:

The buddhas of the present ten directions, these buddhas who wish to give up their lives, I request them to abide for a long time, bringing much benefit and peace, having compassion for the world, and benefiting gods and humans.
